messages.content:
Is there a way to deterministically generate a Private/Public key given a set of fields? I’m looking for a way to do e.g.:

Field(0) -> addr0
Field(1) -> addr1

ofc generating a real PublicKey… maybe even a PublicKey directly without knowing the PrivateKey, but thats probably nonsense 🥸
@gregor please help 🙌
`PublicKey.fromFields([Field(0), Field(1)])` this works 😄
In general, fromFields and all the other Provable interface methods do only the most trivial serialization
So this is definitely not what you want. It creates a private key with 1 bit set

I recommend to use Poseidon hash and then convert with
PrivateKey.fromBigint(hash.toBigint())
Or create a 254 bit bigint in any other deterministic way you want
Important caveat: you have to make sure that your key is not brute forceable. You can achieve that by having a secret random field element (= your root key) which you also put into the Poseidon hash

You can also create a public key (elliptic curve point) directly without knowing the private key. Use Poseidon.hashToGroup() and then PublicKey.fromGroup(). No one will ever be able to find out the private key for that public key
my scenario is rather simple, i have two fields which are known and public, and i wanted to generate a deterministic public key for them, without being able to determine its private key
but this public key generation must be provable
@gregor is this provable tho?
Yes this is provable, seems to be what you're looking for
separate Q, how can i tell which APIs are provable and which not?

Good question, the ones that go from provable types to other provable types will typically be provable (and if not they will say so in their doc comment). The ones that go to/from JS types are never provable
But we could honestly do a better job of clearer marking provable methods
Ideas welcome
best would be if there was an entire namespace dedicated to provable code, like @snarkyjs/provable or so
@gregor `.hashToGroup()` doesnt seem to return a type compatible with `PublicKey.fromGroup()` :/
Take a look at this https://github.com/o1-labs/snarkyjs/blob/main/src/lib/nullifier.ts#L60

embeds.title: snarkyjs/src/lib/nullifier.ts at main · o1-labs/snarkyjs
embeds.description: TypeScript framework for zk-SNARKs and zkApps. Contribute to o1-labs/snarkyjs development by creating an account on GitHub.

messages.content: thanks thats it
@Florian if you were to use PublicKey.fromGroup on the output of `hashToGroup`, how would you do it?
`Group.fromFields([x,x0])`?
Yeah you use Group.fromFields and then PublicKey.fromGroup
ok and going from hashToGroup to Group.fromFields can be done as i wrote above?
There's one nuance: the prover can switch the x0 and x1 outputs from hashToGroup. So the hash output (public key in your case) is not unique. The nullifier implementation handles this
What would you suggest i do to implement a function to deterministically generate a PublicKey from Field[]?

- use hash to group
- assert that x0 is even, like Nullifier.verify() does, to ensure uniqueness of the result
- write a custom 'x, x0 to public key' method which works similar to PublicKey.fromGroup but uses the knowledge that x0 is even to save a lot of constraints (if you use our off the shelf methods then you're basically doing isEven twice, which is super expensive)
